title: path/filepath: Abs can give incorrect results on unix systems
body:
filepath.Abs can give incorrect results on unix systems.  The reason for this is it calls filepath.Clean() which does not take into account symbolic links when handling `..`.  For example in the sample program below it is incorrect to transform `dir2/dir1/../afile` to `dir2/afile` as dir1 is a symbolic link.

> What version of Go are you using (`go version`)?

```
go version go1.6.2 linux/amd64
```

> What operating system and processor architecture are you using (`go env`)?

```
GOARCH="amd64"
GOBIN=""
GOEXE=""
GOHOSTARCH="amd64"
GOHOSTOS="linux"
GOOS="linux"
GOPATH="/home/kevina/gocode2"
GORACE=""
GOROOT="/usr/local/go"
GOTOOLDIR="/usr/local/go/pkg/tool/linux_amd64"
GO15VENDOREXPERIMENT="1"
CC="gcc"
GOGCCFLAGS="-fPIC -m64 -pthread -fmessage-length=0"
CXX="g++"
CGO_ENABLED="1"
```
> What did you do?

Use `filepath.Abs` in combination with symbolic links and `..`

Here is a sample program at https://play.golang.org/p/ZAhkresUaD, but note it won't run on the playground.  To reproduce the results it needs to be run on a Unix system.

The programs creates the following files/dirs/symlink
```
afile
dir1/
dir2/
dir2/dir1 -> ../dir1
```
And than uses the path `dir2/dir1/../afile` to read `afile`.  This correctly resolves when the path it relative or the absolute path is created manually, but fails when filepath.Abs() is used.

The path `/somedir/dir2/dir1/../afile` should resolve to `/somedir/afile`; however filepath.Abs() transforms that to the incorrect `/somedir/dir2/afile`.

> What did you expect to see?

The sample program should run without error.

> What did you see instead?

`open /tmp/abstest062312103/dir2/afile: no such file or directory`
